respondent.name: JAMES V. CROSBY, JR., SECRETARY, FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS. :

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: We'll hear argument now in Aurelio Gonzalez v. James Crosby. Mr. Rashkind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: At that point when the court makes that examination under your rule and it comes to point six - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- does it refer at any point or in any circumstance to AEDPA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, if we were to make clear that 60(b) is widely available, even category six, don't you think -- and as a result the AEDPA restrictions don't apply, don't you think that number would increase rather dramatically?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, there's no language in category six referring to extraordinary circumstances, any other reason justifying relief.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: But it's still very vague.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All that is true, but I think that the court below and the other parties say -- almost everybody is on your side. However, they also note a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 problem, and the problem is that given the very rigid structure of AEDPA and the imagination of lawyers, that if 60(b) hasn't proved an escape hatch for getting around the AEDPA restriction, it will, and that what the lawyers will do is they will reconstruct what they'd like as a second habeas and put it in the form of a 60(b). And so I can accept everything you say, but if that in the back of my mind is a concern running around Congress in this way, what form of words could you put in to restrict 60(b) to its domain which is the domain in which it's been used so far? Now, the Criminal Justice Legal Foundation filed a brief in which they tried to do that. I thought that was a constructive effort. So what's your opinion - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- about how best to do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, but that's - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's pretty flabby.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's pretty flabby. Potentially meritorious? Not probably, potentially.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: But this is going to be taken up by some 800 district judges and a couple hundred appellate judges, and they're the ones who have the final say in most of these cases just because we decide so few.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, aren't we dealing here with a time bar issue?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: I mean, there -- there was not a determination below, but an extraordinary amount of time expired before the application was made. Why would that count as some extraordinary circumstance? Why shouldn't the petitioner be stuck with the time bar? I don't see how this fits even under your proposed rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I was going to ask the same question. It's about as pedestrian an issue as you could get. It comes up all the time. I mean, this is not a cosmic legal issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why -- why did Florida deny relief in -- in the post-conviction? I mean, one reason that looks like it might apply is that Florida had a 2 - year statute of limitations and this was brought up 14 years later.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you saying that counsel -- what -- what he alleges counsel told him was, in fact, accurate at the time counsel said it, that somebody who got a 99-year sentence wouldn't have to serve more than 13 years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But has that been determined - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- by some court? That's the allegation - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- pure and simple - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- yet to be determined.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And so we have to know how the time bar element folds in here, and in an ordinary civil case, a time bar would be an adjudication on the merits. I mean, that -- that would end the case, and why would it be a different, more liberal rule in habeas?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you're -- you're saying it is extraordinary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. Counsel, what -- that - - that brings me to a question that I don't understand about your argument. It seems to me you're biting off more than you have to bite off here. Would you win on the following argument? And I will tell you in advance that it looks to me as though you would. But maybe there's some reason you're not making it. Number one, your statute of limitations claim is not the kind of claim that AEDPA is concerned with when it deals with limits on second and successive petitions. Number two, although a statute of limitations issue is on the merits, it is not on the merits in the second or successive petition category. In this case, you don't have to worry about making a -- an -- an AEDPA end run so far as second or successive goes, and therefore, 60(b) can be used simply not as a wide-open door, but as a door that could be opened when your claim is a claim about a rule that barred you from getting into Federal court, which is what the statute of limitations rule does. That's all you're asking for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And finally, you have an extraordinary situation here because you have a later 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 determination in Artuz which declared the law not as a change in the law, but as what the law presumably meant from day one. As I understand it, if we accepted that argument, you would win. Do you agree?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then why don't you make that argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can you go back to the district court before the Eleventh Circuit? You've now told me that the ground on which the Florida court denied relief was not based on the statute of limitations. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In the Federal court, what is the ground on which relief was denied and how would Artuz affect that decision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but your -- your immediate concern is how do I get into a Federal court. Whether you win or lose once you get in there is another problem, but I -- as I understand it, that's not what we're dealing with here. And -- and the -- you -- you were kept out of the district court on a statute of limitations issue. If you can say -- if you argue all I've got in front of you, us, is a statute of limitations issue, that's all I want under -- to raise under 60(b) and I have an extraordinary claim here because of the subsequent Artuz decision, that will get you into Federal court, if we accept that argument. Whether -- whether you win or lose, once you get there, I don't know, and I don't know that that's before us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You -- you had a question. Remember my -- you were giving me the three principles to prevent the end run.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the first was good cause. The second was potentially meritorious underlying issues, and the third is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May -- may I ask you a question that may be a little bit collateral? There was disagreement on the court of appeals, as I remember it, as to whether or not a COA requirement applies to a denial of a 60(b) motion. What is your view on that issue?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Well, we're not 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 talking about ordinary appellate review. We're talking about an appeal from an adverse decision by a Federal habeas court.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: So that isn't quite as strange as you make it sound.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Well, but maybe that's what Congress wanted. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But why isn't that always the case if it's time-barred?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: If it's time-barred, you never have your chance to have the merits argued.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: But at what point do we bring this all to a halt? I mean, there's always one more argument to make that the last court to rule against me was wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, now, the Federal Government has a different proposed rule than yours. Are you going to comment on their proposal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the -- you -- you said 60(b) fits this like a glove because it's the district court correcting its own errors. But it isn't usually -- 60(b) was framed with the idea of the district 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 court being the very first instance court. And here you will have the district court as the third going up the ladder. So -- and -- and given that the habeas rules say that -- that civil rules are applicable but have to be modified to be compatible with habeas jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the -- the Government, by the way, seems a broader rule than yours. The only thing it rules out is new legal claims or new evidence. I don't see anything in your -- tell me if I'm wrong, but I don't see anywhere where you say we should be able to bring a 60(b) motion based on new legal claims or new evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's what I said. I don't see how the Government hurts you. I think -- I think if you the Government's, you're even better off.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, it's even -- but I want to know why -- why -- there's some reason you don't like the Government, and -- and -- other than fact that they must hurt you in some way. I don't see how it hurts you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- make us - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And under their test too, you say it's applying the same rule of -- it's not a new claim. It's the same claim as -- as -- just that they - - shows that the district judge got it wrong.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Very well, Mr. Rashkind.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Mr. Kise, we'll hear from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Isn't that an exaggeration of how 60(b) works in practice? It isn't that every civil judgment can come back and back again with 60(b) motions. The district courts have been rather disciplined in handling 60(b) motions. So I think you have exaggerated what 60(b) does in the ordinary civil rules context.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But have we seen it in the - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 there are other circuits who do adopt that rule, aren't there? And have we seen the abuse you're describing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, that depends - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I had the same comment or the same reaction as Justice Ginsburg. Forget about the habeas area. Just in -- with general civil judgments, have there been Law Review articles saying that rule 60(b) undermines finality? People kept going back, back, and back. I -- I thought quite the opposite, that we were living very well with rule 60(b).

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. But his -- his whole argument is you, State, get exactly what you're entitled to if I win on 60(b) because what I was entitled to and what you were entitled to was the 1-year statute but subject to the rule in Artuz. That's all you get, State. And what he is saying is, I want to get back into court so that I can have the statute of limitations -- the benefit of the statute of limitations as Artuz construed it. That means you, State, get what you want and I get my one chance. How is that an open door to the abuse that you're talking about?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: He got what Artuz said was an erroneous view of the statute of limitations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And do you -- do you think that there is -- that there is this -- this sort of tidal wave of -- of erroneous statute of limitations determinations that, if Artuz is applied, will suddenly be coming 5, 10, and 20 years into Federal court? I mean, it -- it -- your argument, in relation to his particular claim seems exaggerated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You -- you were there for the purpose of getting him booted out. I mean, you didn't - - you didn't get into the merits of anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, it was not the applicable law at the time. The decision related back to before that hearing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No. Sometimes there are law- changing decisions, but this was not a law-changing decision. It's a decision interpreting what the law was from the date of its enactment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If there had been an Artuz violation and not every statute of limitations determination implicates Artuz.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, what -- what Congress was 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 principally concerned with -- Congress was concerned with two things. It was concerned with second and successive. That's not what is before us. Congress was also concerned with a 1-year statute of limitations. What is before us on that point is that this guy did not get the benefit of the statute of limitations that he had a right to get the benefit of, that there was a flat mistake of law. So by -- by recognizing his statute of limitations claim, we do not open the door to second and successive litigation. We open the door simply to Artuz problems on statute of limitations rulings and that's a pretty narrow category it seems to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Sure. Sure, he does. And if it's second and successive, he's going to get thrown out again.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So that's the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You may -- you may be right, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 but that's what district courts are there for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's also true of (b)(3).

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And not even the Eleventh Circuit said (b)(3). And therefore, you want to say absolute, or are we really talking about which 60(b) motions escape the strictures of AEDPA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you're prepared to defend the -- the Eleventh Circuit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Correct, though you're alone on 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 that because even the Government doesn't and nor does the criminal justice. But if you're prepared to defend them, I guess you'd say why is it that they will allow (b)(3), fraud on the court by the adverse party, to escape, but should your own witness turn out to have been committing his own fraud for whatever set of reasons, you can't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, under I guess the Government, you can bring everything under 60(b). By the way, if they do bring a motion to reopen under 60(b) because of change of law, they're almost bound to lose. There are hardly any cases which find that an adequate ground under 60(b). But they let you do anything under 60(b), I take it, as long as the claims presented do not -- as long as they are not trying to obtain relief on the basis of new legal claims or new evidence. Now, I just noticed there's another one here. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Do not support habeas relief. Maybe that's the problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You explain. I -- I thought when I first read this, that this was quite broad, but I may not have read it perfectly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So is that also true if his own witness has committed the fraud?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: What about a claim that a witness perjured himself, a witness for the government, during trial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And all I'm saying is exactly whatever criteria is met, that it happens to be his own witness, and sometimes your own witnesses do have their little games, you know, with prisoners, and so it's the same thing. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Does that not count too?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Kise, this may be important. Do you agree with Mr. Rashkind that in the Florida court the dismissal or the denial of relief was not on the Florida statute of limitations - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it's not -- not clear from -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's not what the -- this is -- the -- the form of dismissal in the Florida Supreme Court doesn't tell us that. It just says something about allegations contained therein do not constitute legal grounds for granting the new trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The first one was on the statute of limitations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we have that anyplace at -- in the papers before us, the first -- the first dismissal in the Florida -- in the Florida trial court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that it was based on the Florida 2-year statute of limitations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But is it correct that they address the same subject matter? Isn't 60(b) directed at the integrity of the habeas proceeding, whereas AEDPA is directed at the integrity of the original conviction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Didn't Congress rule -- rule out 60(b) in -- in death cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes. I may be wrong about having - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought there was a special provision for capital cases.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Kise. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Ms. Millett, we'll hear from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: On page 24, I read the or wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's -- you meant the things on both sides of the or.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And I was thinking the first side you'd allow, the second side you wouldn't. But if it's very, very strict, which now I understand it, because I read the or correctly when I went back.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My question would be why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Would you say that again?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is that a statement of when it's not available? I want to be sure I -- are you stating it positively or negatively?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It is not available in the circumstance you described. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Now, would you state -- tell us when it is available?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But now you're into -- I mean, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 you can use a tone of voice. You know, it sounds very strong. But I thought 60(b)(6) is weird things happen, and 60(b)(1) is there are all kinds of mistakes. You know, some of them can just be accidental. The lawyer was hit by a trolley. And in fact, all of 60(b) is meant to capture that kind of thing. So it sounds like what you're saying is, sure, follow 60(b), maybe not the evidentiary, maybe not the new evidence part, follow it, but be sure you do so strictly. Are you saying more than that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Where -- where do you disagree with Judge Carnes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: With -- with the majority of -- in -- in the Eleventh Circuit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Now, how do you apply it in this case, the Artuz problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, suppose Artuz had been decided and it was in the mail and the judge forgot to open his advance sheets that day. And so he goes back to his office, says, oh, my God. You know, I mean, a weird thing like that. And of course, he says nobody has been 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 hurt yet. I'll reopen it. Okay? Is that all right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, it's 10 days and a half.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the reason that it's happened is because all the lawyers were hit by four trolleys. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, you see what I'm doing? I'm simply trying to find cases that fit within the language, but they're very weird and justice cries out for a reopening. Now, that's what it seems to me one is about. Two is about. Three doesn't really. Three you agree applies. Two may not apply. Three you agree applies. Four I think you probably agree applies or not at all. Five doesn't apply at all, and six is anything under the sun.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, maybe --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- maybe the district court shouldn't have done that, but whatever -- whatever was wrong there, it was merely a classic application of -- of review of a statute of limitations point. There -- there was much else involved and maybe it was improper. My question, I guess, is why do you say that the -- why do you assume that the policy animating applying 60(b) to a gatekeeping issue like statute of limitations, where there is an unusual circumstance as in Artuz, should be the same policy that animates applying 60(b), let's 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 say, when there is an attempt to -- to make an end run around the second and successive rules? The latter I think we can all understand pretty readily. I mean, it's very important. You've got the - - the -- AEDPA if you allow that. With respect to this kind of a statute of limitations problem, what the guy is asking for is what he was entitled to under AEDPA as a matter of timing and gatekeeping. Why is the policy under 60(b) the same in those two cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did the Federal court make a mistake of -- of law if the -- if the Florida court dismissed under the Florida 2-year statute of limitations? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No, no. Did the Federal court. And suppose that the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's sub judice, before us now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But do you agree with Mr. Kise that the first dismissal in the Florida court, the first denial was on the Florida 2-year statute of limitations?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Millett. Mr. Rashkind, you have 4 minutes left. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Rashkind. The case is submitted.
